Avoid the Assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand: In 1914, the assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria-Hungary by Gavrilo Princip in Sarajevo, Bosnia, sparked the outbreak of World War I. Changing this event could have prevented the devastating conflict that ensued, including the loss of millions of lives, widespread destruction, and a global economic downturn. By altering this event, it could have led to a more peaceful and diplomatic resolution to the political tensions of the time, potentially avoiding the war altogether.

Prevent the Sinking of the Titanic: The sinking of the Titanic in 1912 was one of the deadliest maritime disasters in history, resulting in the loss of over 1,500 lives. If this event could be changed, it could have saved countless lives and prevented the immense emotional and economic toll on the survivors and their families. By altering the course of the ship or providing more effective safety measures, it could have prevented the tragedy from occurring.

Stop the Eruption of Mount Vesuvius: In 79 AD, the eruption of Mount Vesuvius in Italy destroyed the Roman cities of Pompeii and Herculaneum, killing thousands of people. Changing this event could have spared the lives of those who perished and preserved the ancient cities and their cultural heritage. By altering the geological conditions or providing advanced warning systems, it could have prevented the devastating consequences of the eruption.

Avoid the Attack on Pearl Harbor: The attack on Pearl Harbor by the Japanese in 1941 led to the United States' entry into World War II and the subsequent loss of thousands of lives. Changing this event could have prevented the war from expanding to other regions and potentially led to a more peaceful resolution. By altering the political and military strategies of the time, it could have avoided the devastating consequences of the attack.
